p: Ensure the application automatically locks inactive user accounts. Verify that all instances of locking inactive accounts are logged.
Inactive user accounts increase the attack surface of the application and can be used by an attacker as a means of entry.
Follow these steps during the design phase to make sure your application has the capability to lock its inactive user accounts:

Verify that your application stores the user's last login/inactivity information. Check if your application has the necessary procedures in place to store and retrieve last login and lockout information about its users. Common locations for storing such information are:

Verify that your application has a lockout policy. An account lockout policy is typically application specific. Review your application's requirements and design specifications. Check for the following functionality:
Verify that the lockout policy is enforced by default. Make sure the functionality that enforces the lockout policy is enabled by default during deployment.
To automatically lock inactive user accounts:

Set a lockout policy. Create the application's lockout policy. Determine the necessary duration of inactivity before an account can be locked/disabled. This policy can vary depending on whether the account is of a normal user or an administrator. For example, disable normal accounts after 45 days of inactivity and administrative accounts after 30 days of inactivity.

Keep track of user inactivity. Establish a mechanism to keep track of the last successful authentication. Successful authentication can be tracked via logs or a timestamp, which resides in the user database. Example:

Set a lockout mechanism. Establish a mechanism 
to verify the current period of inactivity and automatically set the 
disabled bit for inactive accounts. Use the application or database 
server's scheduler to run this function during the hours with least user
 activity. Keep in mind that inactive accounts should be disabled, but 
not removed until it is confirmed that they should be completely 
removed.

For example, the following database transaction would lock all 
user accounts that have been inactive for more than 30 days. Such a 
transaction should be scheduled to run once a day:
Note: PCI DSS requirements state that a user account should be locked out after no more than 90 days of inactivity.

The following segment illustrates the user database of a multi-user application. In its current state, the application logs the last time the user has logged in but does not enforce a lockout policy for its inactive users. Therefore, an attacker can gain unauthorized access to the application by compromising an inactive account.

The following segment illustrates the user database of a multi-user application. Because the application enforces a lockout policy, all of its inactive users have been locked and denied access to the application. Therefore, an attacker cannot compromise the application through its inactive users.
ol:
Verify that your application stores the user's last login/inactivity information. Check if your application has the necessary procedures in place to store and retrieve last login and lockout information about its users. Common locations for storing such information are:
      
        Database that stores user account information
        Data structures that represent user accounts
        Routines that handle user login
        Routines that retrieve and update user account information
      
    
    
      
        Verify that your application has a lockout policy. An account lockout policy is typically application specific. Review your application's requirements and design specifications. Check for the following functionality:
      
        A mechanism for determining user inactivity
        A mechanism for locking inactive accounts
        A mechanism for unlocking disabled accounts
        Verify that the last-login timestamp is reset to the current timestamp upon a successful authentication attempt
      
    
    
      
        Verify that the lockout policy is enforced by default. Make sure the functionality that enforces the lockout policy is enabled by default during deployment.
      
        Ensure that only users with administrative privileges can amend your application's lockout policy.
        Verify that all instances of modifying the lockout policy are logged.
        Check the following locations in the code to determine if the lockout policy is fully enforced:Account administration routinesBackground database processes that perform user account maintenanceAuthentication routines

Set a lockout policy. Create the application's lockout policy. Determine the necessary duration of inactivity before an account can be locked/disabled. This policy can vary depending on whether the account is of a normal user or an administrator. For example, disable normal accounts after 45 days of inactivity and administrative accounts after 30 days of inactivity.
    
    
      
        Keep track of user inactivity. Establish a mechanism to keep track of the last successful authentication. Successful authentication can be tracked via logs or a timestamp, which resides in the user database. Example:
      
        For Mongodb:
      
      
      > db.users.find({},{_id:0,username:1,last_login_date:1})+----------+-----------------+| username | last_login_date |+----------+-----------------+| adam     |  2013-05-11     || jill     |  2012-12-14     || jack     |  2013-05-10     || dinesh   |  2013-05-11     || zane     |  2001-09-23     || sam      |  2005-06-19     |+----------+-----------------+
      For MySql:
      sql> select username, last_login_date from users;+----------+-----------------+| username | last_login_date |+----------+-----------------+| adam     |  2013-05-11     || jill     |  2012-12-14     || jack     |  2013-05-10     || dinesh   |  2013-05-11     || zane     |  2001-09-23     || sam      |  2005-06-19     |+----------+-----------------+
    
    
      
        Set a lockout mechanism. Establish a mechanism 
to verify the current period of inactivity and automatically set the 
disabled bit for inactive accounts. Use the application or database 
server's scheduler to run this function during the hours with least user
 activity. Keep in mind that inactive accounts should be disabled, but 
not removed until it is confirmed that they should be completely 
removed. 
      For example, the following database transaction would lock all 
user accounts that have been inactive for more than 30 days. Such a 
transaction should be scheduled to run once a day:
      Update users set locked = 1 where (current_date - 30) > last_login_date

pre: Update users set locked = 1 where (current_date - 30) > last_login_date
sql> select username, locked, last_login_date from users;

html:
Applies to

Scala and Play Framework 2.1.0+

What to Check For

Ensure the application automatically locks inactive user accounts. Verify that all instances of locking inactive accounts are logged.

Why

Inactive user accounts increase the attack surface of the application and can be used by an attacker as a means of entry.

How to Check

Follow these steps during the design phase to make sure your application has the capability to lock its inactive user accounts:

  1. Verify that your application stores the user's last login/inactivity information. Check if your application has the necessary procedures in place to store and retrieve last login and lockout information about its users. Common locations for storing such information are:

    • Database that stores user account information
    • Data structures that represent user accounts
    • Routines that handle user login
    • Routines that retrieve and update user account information

  2. Verify that your application has a lockout policy. An account lockout policy is typically application specific. Review your application's requirements and design specifications. Check for the following functionality:

    • A mechanism for determining user inactivity
    • A mechanism for locking inactive accounts
    • A mechanism for unlocking disabled accounts
    • Verify that the last-login timestamp is reset to the current timestamp upon a successful authentication attempt

  3. Verify that the lockout policy is enforced by default. Make sure the functionality that enforces the lockout policy is enabled by default during deployment.

    • Ensure that only users with administrative privileges can amend your application's lockout policy.
    • Verify that all instances of modifying the lockout policy are logged.
    • Check the following locations in the code to determine if the lockout policy is fully enforced:
      • Account administration routines
      • Background database processes that perform user account maintenance
      • Authentication routines

How to Fix

To automatically lock inactive user accounts:

  1. Set a lockout policy. Create the application's lockout policy. Determine the necessary duration of inactivity before an account can be locked/disabled. This policy can vary depending on whether the account is of a normal user or an administrator. For example, disable normal accounts after 45 days of inactivity and administrative accounts after 30 days of inactivity.

  2. Keep track of user inactivity. Establish a mechanism to keep track of the last successful authentication. Successful authentication can be tracked via logs or a timestamp, which resides in the user database. Example:

    For Mongodb: 

    > db.users.find({},{_id:0,username:1,last_login_date:1})
    +----------+-----------------+
    | username | last_login_date |
    +----------+-----------------+
    | adam     |  2013-05-11     |
    | jill     |  2012-12-14     |
    | jack     |  2013-05-10     |
    | dinesh   |  2013-05-11     |
    | zane     |  2001-09-23     |
    | sam      |  2005-06-19     |
    +----------+-----------------+
    For MySql: 
    sql> select username, last_login_date from users;
    +----------+-----------------+
    | username | last_login_date |
    +----------+-----------------+
    | adam     |  2013-05-11     |
    | jill     |  2012-12-14     |
    | jack     |  2013-05-10     |
    | dinesh   |  2013-05-11     |
    | zane     |  2001-09-23     |
    | sam      |  2005-06-19     |
    +----------+-----------------+

  3. Set a lockout mechanism. Establish a mechanism to verify the current period of inactivity and automatically set the disabled bit for inactive accounts. Use the application or database server's scheduler to run this function during the hours with least user activity. Keep in mind that inactive accounts should be disabled, but not removed until it is confirmed that they should be completely removed.

    For example, the following database transaction would lock all user accounts that have been inactive for more than 30 days. Such a transaction should be scheduled to run once a day:

    Update users set locked = 1 where (current_date - 30) > last_login_date

Note: PCI DSS requirements state that a user account should be locked out after no more than 90 days of inactivity.

Problem Example

The following segment illustrates the user database of a multi-user application. In its current state, the application logs the last time the user has logged in but does not enforce a lockout policy for its inactive users. Therefore, an attacker can gain unauthorized access to the application by compromising an inactive account.

For Mongodb: 

> db.users.find({},{_id:0,username:1,locked:1,last_login_date:1})
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| username | locked | last_login_date |
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| adam     |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| jill     |      0 |      2012-12-14 |
| jack     |      0 |      2013-05-10 |
| dinesh   |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| zane     |      0 |      2001-09-23 |
| sam      |      0 |      2005-06-19 |
+----------+--------+-----------------+
For MySql: 

sql> select username, locked, last_login_date from users;
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| username | locked | last_login_date |
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| adam     |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| jill     |      0 |      2012-12-14 |
| jack     |      0 |      2013-05-10 |
| dinesh   |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| zane     |      0 |      2001-09-23 |
| sam      |      0 |      2005-06-19 |
+----------+--------+-----------------+

Solution Example

The following segment illustrates the user database of a multi-user application. Because the application enforces a lockout policy, all of its inactive users have been locked and denied access to the application. Therefore, an attacker cannot compromise the application through its inactive users.

sql> select username, locked, last_login_date from users;
For Mongodb: 
> db.users.find({},{_id:0,username:1,locked:1,last_login_date:1})
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| username | locked | last_login_date |
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| adam     |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| jill     |      1 |      2012-12-14 |
| jack     |      0 |      2013-05-10 |
| dinesh   |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| zane     |      1 |      2001-09-23 |
| sam      |      1 |      2005-06-19 |
+----------+--------+-----------------+
For MySql: 
sql> select username, locked, last_login_date from users;
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| username | locked | last_login_date |
+----------+--------+-----------------+
| adam     |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| jill     |      1 |      2012-12-14 |
| jack     |      0 |      2013-05-10 |
| dinesh   |      0 |      2013-05-11 |
| zane     |      1 |      2001-09-23 |
| sam      |      1 |      2005-06-19 |
+----------+--------+-----------------+
